eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Manage life points by damaging or healing the object.
Use damage cooldown to prevent further damage during the cooldown. 

Properties:
- Health
- Max Health
- Damage Cooldown (seconds)

Conditions:
- Is dead (no health points)
- Is just damaged

Actions:
- Damage the object (reduce health)
- Heal the object (increase health)
- Set current health
- Set maximum health
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Health
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Manage life points by damaging or healing the object.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Ideal for explosions, hit/impacts, earthquake, etc.

Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position:  Shake the X and/or Y position of the camera 
- Angle: Shake the rotation of the camera 
- Zoom: Shake the zoom level of the camera 

Control how the camera shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the camera moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the camera
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each change of the movement of the camera
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)

Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers 
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Camera is not shaking" 
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters. 
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake the camera on the specified layer using one or more methods of shaking (position, angle, zoom).

eventsFunctions.description: Shake the camera on the specified layer, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, zoom).
eventsFunctions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer
Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the X axis (pixels) (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (pixels) (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerY

events.comment: Keep shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
DisplacementAngle = ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate clockwise (this includes the initial shake and can be used for a one shake effect)
DisplacementAngle = -1 * ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude
Calculate Zoom shake
Calculate camera zoom displacement, with linear decay over time
ZoomDisplacement = ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase zoom
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ZoomDisplacement = -1 * ((DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration) * Amplitude *  1/100
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Change zoom
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Change angle
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Change zoom
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached or if stop shaking has been requested

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables

eventsFunctions.description: Check if camera is shaking.
eventsFunctions.name: IsShaking

eventsFunctions.description: Stop shaking the camera.
eventsFunctions.name: StopShaking

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy, daliyoucefmedakram@gmail.com, @bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Animate the text to simulate it being written character by character (also called "typewriter" effect), with a customizable time between each character. Useful for dialogue scenes or visual novels.

Add the behavior to a Text object (BBText, Bitmap Text object) and choose the interval between characters.

* When the text changes, the automatic typing starts again from the beginning with the new text.
* You can change the speed of the text typing by changing the interval with events.
* Use a condition to check if the typing finished.
* You can also pause the typing and resume it after.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.fullName: Auto typing animation for texts ("typewriter" effect)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time

A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.
eventsFunctions.name: WaitAndCatchUp
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delay the camera of _PARAM0_ during: _PARAM2_ seconds according to the maximum speed _PARAM3_;_PARAM4_ seconds and catch up in _PARAM5_ seconds

events.comment: Maybe the catch-up show be done in constant pixel speed instead of constant time speed.

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.name: AddForecastHistoryPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Add the time:_PARAM2_ and position: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_ to the forecast history of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Elairyx, @Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Allows to set up checkpoints for each instance.
Checkpoint coordinates are dynamic values so can be object positions absolute/relative values and more.
Checkpoints can then be used to move the same or even other instances to them.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Checkpoints

eventsFunctions.description: Update a checkpoint of an object.
eventsFunctions.name: SaveCheckpoint

eventsFunctions.description: Change the position of the object to the saved checkpoint.
eventsFunctions.name: LoadCheckpoint

parameters.longDescription: Loading not yet saved checkpoints will (by default) set the position to the coordinate 0;0. Select "yes" to completely ignore non-existant checkpoints. To define an alternative checkpoint for it, create a new event and use the "Checkpoint exists" condition, save the wanted checkpoint as the action.
parameters.name: SetIgnoreUndefined

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a checkpoint has a position saved / does exist.
eventsFunctions.name: CheckpointExist

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, axis force, trigger pressure, deadzone for each gamepad, etc...

Up to 4 gamepads can be connected. For each condition or expression, you'll have to enter the index of the gamepad to read. This is 1, 2, 3 or 4.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of the pressure on a gamepad trigger.
eventsFunctions.name: TriggerPressure

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the force value of a gamepad stick.
0 is stick on default position, 1 is at the maximum.
eventsFunctions.name: StickForce

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the rotation value of a gamepad stick.
If the deadzone value is high, the angle value is rounded to main axes, left, left, up, down.
An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.
eventsFunctions.name: StickRotationValue

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of axis of a gamepad stick.
eventsFunctions.name: AxisValue

eventsFunctions.description:
Test if a button is released on a gamepad. Buttons can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Other: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT".
eventsFunctions.name: C_Button_released

eventsFunctions.description: Return the index of the last pressed button of a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: LastButtonID

eventsFunctions.description: Check if any button is pressed on a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Any_Button_pressed
eventsFunctions.sentence: Any button of gamepad _PARAM1_ is pressed

eventsFunctions.description:
Return the last button pressed. 
Buttons for Xbox and PS4 can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Both: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT".
eventsFunctions.name: LastButtonString

eventsFunctions.description:
Check if a button is pressed on a gamepad. 
Buttons can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Other: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT".
eventsFunctions.name: C_Button_pressed

eventsFunctions.description: Return the value of the deadzone applied to a gamepad sticks, between 0 and 1.
eventsFunctions.name: Deadzone

eventsFunctions.description: Set the deadzone for sticks of the gamepad. The deadzone is an area for which movement on sticks won't be taken into account (instead, the stick will be considered as not moved). Deadzone is between 0 and 1, and is by default 0.2.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Set_deadzone
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set deadzone for sticks on gamepad: _PARAM1_ to _PARAM2_

parameters.description: Deadzone for sticks, 0.2 by default (0 to 1)
parameters.name: deadzone

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a stick of a gamepad is pushed in a given direction.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Axis_pushed
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM2_ stick of gamepad _PARAM1_ is pushed in direction _PARAM3_

eventsFunctions.description: Return the number of connected gamepads.
eventsFunctions.name: ConnectedGamepadsCount

eventsFunctions.description: Return a string containing informations about the specified gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: GamepadType

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the specified gamepad has the specified information in its description. Useful to know if the gamepad is a Xbox or PS4 controller.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Controller_type

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a gamepad is connected.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Controller_X_is_connected

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a vibration on the specified controller. Might only work if the game is running in a recent web browser.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Vibrate_controller

parameters.description: Time of the vibration, in seconds (optional, default value is 1)
parameters.name: duration

eventsFunctions.description: Check if any button is released on a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: C_any_button_released
eventsFunctions.sentence: Any button of gamepad _PARAM1_ is released
